dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN across an empty parking lot until we find a single car, a Lada Riva-- there all by itself in front of a drab generic Soviet building on the outskirts of a city.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: But those country tracks our ancestors followed / the graves where they lie with the old Russian cross /

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room with multiple lab desks, sinks, cabinets and racks of scientific equipment, periodic table charts on t walls, labels with the familiar RADIATION sign...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: I feel that for me, it was countryside Russia / that first made me feel I must truly belong / to the tedious miles between village and village / the tears of the widow, the women's sad song / The room is empty but for: A WOMAN, 40's - FACE DOWN at a table, her salt-and-pepper hair splayed around her head. Next to her, a stack of technical documents. Coffee cup. Half-eaten sandwich. Soviet poetry droning from a RADIO. We PUSH IN on her. She might be dead.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: We see alongside us the deaths of our comrades / by old Russian practice, soldiers laid end to end / We stay on the woman. Hear the SOUND of the lab door ope

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: And yet I still feel proud of the dearest of countries / The great bitter land I was born to defend. Someone enters. Drops a small paper bag next to her HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: That was Konstantin Simonov's poem "to Alexei Surkov," written in-- CLICK. The unseen person turns the radio off, and ULANA KHOMYUK, the sleeping woman, raises her head.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: (disoriented) Whumm? DMITRI, 30, puts a THERMOS in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: You work too hard. Khomyuk rubs her face. Checks her watch. Then looks aroun

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Where is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: They refused to come in.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: It's Saturday. Oh. Right. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Why did you come in?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: I work too hard. (wipes his brow) Uch, it's boiling in here. He crosses to a WINDOW. He LIFTS the window OPEN, and almost instantly:

dialogues.speaker: BEEEEEEEEEEEEEE
dialogues.text: 204 205 Dmitri and Khomyuk turn in adrenaline shock to: a DOSIMET mounted on the wall. A split second, then: Dmitri SLAMS the window shut. Then rushes to the dosimete Presses a button to silence the alarm. Reads the meter.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Eight milliroentgen. What-- ? Dmitri anxiously glances at a METAL CASE with radiation stickers. Inside, boxes and tubes.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: A leak? Khomyuk hasn't taken her eyes off the window. Wide awake now.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: No. It would have gone off before. It's coming from outside. Dmitri sits down. Has the unthinkable finally happened?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: The Americans? IN CUTS - Khomyuk opens her drawer, pulls out a PILL CONTAINER. Takes one pill. Then tosses him the bottle. Snaps on LATEX GLOVES. Tears open a PACKET. A sterile WET WIPE sample cloth is removed, folded... Khomyuk WIPES along the SILL of the WINDOW in an "Ss" pattern, pressing firmly, picking up dust, and then we're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khomyuk strides with purpose down the empty hall, sample hand. There's iron in this woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SPECTROMETER - HUMS - Khomyuk stares at the screen. Eyes flickering over the spiking lines. One line spikes much higher than the other. And just like that, she knows.  206

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khomyuk barrels back into the lab, startling the waiting Dmitri. She thrusts the SPECTROMETER PRINTOUT at him.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Iodine 131. It's not military. It's uranium decay. U-235.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Reactor fuel. He looks at her. Then catches up. A sick realization.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Ignalina. Maybe 240 kilometers away. She turns to a shelf of BINDERS... pulls one, flips pages There. She picks up the lab phone. Dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: IGNALINA OPERATOR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: (rushed, loud) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Yes, this is Ulana Khomyuk with the Institute of Nuclear--

dialogues.speaker: IGNALINA OPERATOR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: You don't think we already know? We're looking for it!

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Looking for--

dialogues.speaker: IGNALINA OPERATOR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: We've got 4 milliroentgen here, I've got men crawling over the whole plant... no steam leak, no water leak, nothing! We can't--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: All right, stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: IGNALINA OPERATOR, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Don't tell me to stay calm, I want to evacuate, Moscow tells us we can't, and now you call? Who the hell are you anyway-- Khomyuk hangs up on him. No time for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're at 4. It's not them. Who's the next closest?

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Chernobyl. But that's not possible, it's 400 kilometers away.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: No, too far for 8 milliroentgen. They'd have to be split open. But maybe they know something. She finds the number in her directory, and dials. We hear the other end - ring ring. As they wait:

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Could it be a waste dump?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: We'd be seeing other isotopes. ring ring... ring ring...

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Nuclear test? New kind of bomb?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: We would have heard. That's what half our people work on here. ring ring... ring ring...

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Something with the space program? Like a satellite or-- what are they saying down there?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I don't know. No one's answering the phone. Khomyuk and Dmitri realize at the same time. She puts the receiver down on the table, and now he can hear it too. ring ring... ring ring... ring ring... ring ring... Oh god. The ring of the the unanswered phone grows LOUDER and LOUDER, blending into the sound of A SIREN as we CUT TO:  207 208 209

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EMERGENCY VEHICLE screeches to a halt in front of the building. We follow-- handheld-- chaos-- as emergency workers WHEEL a patient rapidly into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madness. A war zone. The building is choked with people: firemen, plant workers, men, women, children, babies... Some people are vomiting. Others are passed out. Children screaming. ZINCHENKO pushes through the crowd. Issuing instructions to a frantic PRIPYAT NURSE who follows her.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Get everyone started on an IV.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT NURSE
dialogues.text: We don't have enough.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: All the children then.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT NURSE
dialogues.text: We don't have enough.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: (snaps) As many as you can! Just-- (looks around) Where's the old man?

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT NURSE
dialogues.text: He's set up a burn ward in 16. Shit. Zinchenko leaves the panicking nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men on gurneys. Some are screaming in pain. Zinchenko ENTERS... wobbles slightly in a puddle of vomit on the floor. Fuck. Regains her balance and sees: THE OLD DOCTOR - dabbing at VASILY'S FACE with a wet sponge, which he's dipping in a basin of WHITE FLUID.

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: What are you doing? What is that?  210 211

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Milk. Much better than water. My god. Zinchenko scans the men. We recognize Vasily. Akimov. Toptunov. Sees the patterns of the burns on their skin. Bodies swollen. Skin strangely tanned. Dark. Zinchenko grabs the sponge out of the old doctor's hand. Flings it aside. Then starts PULLING Vasily's BOOTS off.

dialogues.speaker: OLD DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: These are radiation burns. Their clothes are contaminated. Everyone stares in silence. Until:

dialogues.speaker: HELP ME.
dialogues.text: The nurses are jarred into action. As they strip away pants, jackets, helmets, shirts, socks, underwear...

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Get it all off. We're taking it down to the basement. The old doctor watches in utter confusion. The basement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feet STAMPEDE down the winding stairway. EQUIPMENT and CLOTHING hits the concrete floor in a jumbl pile. The nurses run back up for more as other nurses com down and toss more clothing. Zinchenko hurls her handful of clothing to the floor. The winces. Checks her hand where she was holding Vasily's BOOT. Her palm is already BRIGHT RED. She looks up to see a nurse staring. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: ZINCHENKO
dialogues.text: Let's get the rest. Zinchenko heads back for more. The nurse follows, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOB of angry people are yelling and pleading with: A LI OF MILITARY POLICE, some with guns, some holding clubs.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL SOLDIER
dialogues.text: We are at capacity. Please disperse! LYUDMILLA is JOSTLED by the crowd. Near the front, the soldiers physically PUSH people back. There's a SURGE of movement from behind her... the soldiers PUSH back... and in the chaos, she SLIPS past them... FALLS... ...then gets up and RUNS into the hospital. The soldiers can't stop her. Too busy with the rest of the crowd. The air fills with angry shouts and screams, and then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. A stately corridor. Chandeliers. Floors shined to a polis And every few feet, the Soviet flag. VALERY LEGASOV sits on a small chair against the wall nea one of the flags. Hair carefully combed. His best suit. A door opens, and a woman, 40's, emerges. Pleasant. Court

dialogues.speaker: KREMLIN AIDE
dialogues.text: Professor Legasov?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (rises) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KREMLIN AIDE
dialogues.text: Oh no, not yet. They're finishing up some other business. It'll be a few more minutes. Can I get you some tea?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. Thank you. She extends a document to him.

dialogues.speaker: KREMLIN AIDE
dialogues.text: I thought you might care to read Deputy Secretary Shcherbina's report while you wait.  214 215

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Oh. Certainly. Thank you. He takes the typewritten report, and she exits. Legasov sits back down. Scans the first page. Hmm. Flip. Second page. Scanning. Mmhmm. Flip. Third page. Scanning. Wait. Oh my god. He sits there, staring agape at the page. Then looks around... is anyone else here? Has anyone else seen-- ?? The aide returns. Still pleasant and calm.

dialogues.speaker: KREMLIN AIDE
dialogues.text: All right, Professor. They're ready. She sees the panic in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KREMLIN AIDE
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE LEAD: Legasov, on his face, watching as he forces himself to walk... forces himself to stay calm, the repor clutched in his hand, still open to the third page. Surely they know. They have to know... He wipes his brow. Sweat. Mouth dry. He passes SOLDIERS who push open doors, and he enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inner sanctum. The center of Soviet power. A long room lined with Soviet flags. In the center of the room, a conference table. Men in the seats. Some in Soviet military uniforms. Others in suits. And at the head of the table, MIKHAIL GORBACHEV.  10. Legasov's eyes dart nervously. Who among these men knows? Who else is frightened? Who else feels sick to their stomach? Not one of them appears concerned at all. Someone clears their throat, catching his attention. This is BORIS SHCHERBINA, 67, barrel-chested, intimidatin brow. A bull of a man. And Shcherbina nods toward a seat. As in: we are all sitting. You are not. Sit. Legasov rushes himself into his chair. Trying to keep his hands from shaking. Please. Let someone else say it. Not me. Anyone but me.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Thank you all for your duty to this Commission. We'll begin with Deputy Chairman Shcherbina's briefing, and then we'll discuss next steps if necessary. If necessary?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Thank you, General Secretary. I am pleased to report the situation in Chernobyl is stable. What?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: We're coordinating with local Party officials and plant management to address the incident. Military and civilian patrols have secured the region, and Colonel-General Pikalov, who commands troops specializing in chemical hazards, has been dispatched to the plant. Legasov looks down at page three. Flips to the next page, hoping that there's something that makes page three not real. But page three is real.  11.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: In terms of radiation, Plant Director Bryukhanov reports no more than 3.6 roentgen. I'm told that's the equivalent of a chest x-ray. (to the room) So if you're overdue for a check-up... The men chuckle. Legasov looks up again, eyes passing ove all of them, desperately searching for someone to meet ey with him, to say, "Yes, I know, I'll say it..."

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: As for the fire, it's largely contained. Pikalov and his men should have it out soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Foreign press?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (proudly) Totally unaware. Shcherbina nods across the table to CHARKOV, 63. Of all the Soviet men... the balding, white-haired men wi round faces and black-rimmed glasses... Charkov is perhap the most exemplary of the type. As if he were made in a factory.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: KGB First Deputy Chairman Charkov assures me we've successfully protected our security interests.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Good. Very good. Well, it seems like it's well in hand-- Someone say something. Now. Say it.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: --so if there's nothing else? Legasov's mouth won't open. Tongue won't work.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Meeting adjourned. Gorbachev rises. Everyone else gets up, and--  12.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: No! Everyone turns to him. Shocked.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Pardon me? Legasov realizes he said it. He said no. To Mikhail Gorbachev. And he's terrified. But--

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: We can't adjourn. Shcherbina fixes a dark gaze on Legasov. There's a disquieting rage in this man.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: This is Professor Legasov of the Kurchatov Institute. Professor, if you have a concern, feel free to address it with me. Later. Legasov gives a small nod. Cowed. Dying inside. But:

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I can't. All eyes on him again. Everyone standing. And now he rise Sweaty, flustered, bad suit, crooked glasses.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm so sorry but-- (the report) Page three-- the section on casualties-вЂ” (reading) "A fireman was severely burned on his hand by a chunk of smooth, black mineral on the ground outside the reactor building." Smooth black mineral! (does no one--?) Graphite. There's graphite on the ground. Outside.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: There was a tank explosion. There's debris. Of what importance is-- ?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: There's only one place in the entire facility where you'll find graphite. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV (cont'd) Inside the core. If there's graphite on the ground, it means it wasn't a control system tank that exploded. (beat) It was the reactor core. (the unthinkable) It's open. No one is sure how to react. And so they do what they hav always done. They slowly turn toward Gorbachev to see how they should feel about this. For a moment, he is inscrutable. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Comrade Shcherbina?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: General-Secretary, I assure you Professor Legasov is mistaken. Bryukhanov reports the reactor core is intact. And the radiation-- Legasov's panic ferments to frustration. Impatience. The words come flying out of him.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes, "3.6 roentgen", which by the way is not the equivalent of one chest x-ray, but rather four hundred chest x-rays. That number's been bothering me for a different reason, though. It's also the maximum reading on low-limit dosimeters. They gave us the number they had, but I think the true number is much, much higher. If I'm right, this fireman was holding the equivalent of four million x-rays. In his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (icy) . Professor Legasov. There is no place for alarmist hysteria in this room.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: It's not alarmist if it's a fact!

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: I don't hear any facts at all.  14. The room falls silent. A palpable sense of fear.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: All I hear is a man I don't know engaging in conjecture-- in direct contradiction of what has been reported by Party officials. Shcherbina can barely repress a smile. And Legasov remembers where he is. Who he's yelling in front of. Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I apologize. I didn't mean-- may I express my concern as calmly and respectfully as I can? Shcherbina is about to cut him off, but Gorbachev raises hand to silence him. Then gestures to Legasov to continue and sits. The rest of the room sits back down with him.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: An RBMK reactor uses uranium-235 as fuel. Every atom of U-235 is like a bullet traveling nearly the speed of light, penetrating everything in its path. Wood, metal, concrete, flesh. In every gram of U-235, there are over a billion trillion of these bullets. (beat) That's in one gram. Chernobyl holds over three million grams of U-235. And right now, it is on fire. And-- I believe-- exposed. Wind will carry radioactive particles across the entire continent, and rain will bring them down on us. Three million billion trillion bullets in the water we drink, the food we eat, in the air we breathe. Each bullet-- capable of damaging the genetic code in our bodies. Each bullet capable of bringing sickness, cancer, death. Most of them will not stop firing for a hundred years. Some of them will not stop for fifty thousand years. The air has gone out of the room. No one says a word. The  216 15.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: And this-- concern-- stems entirely from the description of a rock? Everyone turns to stare at Legasov. Dead eyes, all of the

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes. A moment. Then Gorbachev turns to Shcherbina:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: I want you to go to Chernobyl. Look at the reactor. You personally. Report directly back to me.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: A wise decision. I'll depart at once.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: And take Legasov with you. Legasov and Shcherbina both register surprise.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Comrade General- Secretary, but-вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Do you know how a nuclear reactor works, Boris Evdokimovich?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Then how will you know what you're looking at? Gorbachev strides out, followed by everyone else, until there's no one left in the room but Legasov and Shcherbin Staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NOISE of HELICOPTER ROTORS. Two SOLDIERS hold on to their hats as they lead the way toward the helicopters. Legasov walks beside Shcherbina, trying to keep up with the older man's athletic pace.  217 16.

dialogues.speaker: I./E. HELICOPTER MID-FLIGHT
dialogues.text: IN THE BACK - Legasov is sandwiched between the two soldiers. White knuckles. Across from him, a very calm Shcherbina. Legasov is the only one wearing his seat belt

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Did you enjoy the meeting? Legasov isn't quite sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: You should know, it's not the first time someone's tried to embarrass me like that. I've been part of the apparatus for over forty years now. Men like you come along all the time. So smart. So confident. (beat) Funny. I can't remember any of their names. (beat) How does a nuclear reactor work?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: It's a simple question.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: It's hardly a simple answer.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Of course-- you presume I'm too stupid to understand. So I'll restate. Tell me how a nuclear reactor works, or I'll have one of these soldiers throw you out of this helicopter. Legasov slowly looks at the soldiers. Neither one of them seems fazed by that suggestion in the slightest. Okay...

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: So-- a nuclear reactor generates electricity with steam. Shcherbina nods. Good. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: The steam turns a turbine, which generates electricity. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV (cont'd) But where a typical power plant makes steam by burning coal, a nuclear plant-- Legasov pats his jacket pockets. Looking for-- Shcherbina calmly hands Legasov a pen and a copy of the report he just presented. Legasov nods in nervous thanks. Turns the document over, and begins sketching as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: --a nuclear plant uses something called fission. We take an unstable element like uranium-235, which has too many neutrons. A neutron is--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: The bullet.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes. The bullet. So, bullets are flying off of the uranium. He shows Shcherbina the page as he sketches.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Now, if you put enough of these uranium atoms close together, the bullets from one atom will eventually hit another atom. The force of this impact splits that atom apart, releasing a tremendous amount of energy. Fission. But-- that fissioning atom releases even more bullets, which slam into even more atoms. More fission leads to more fission-- and the result is a chain reaction. (beat) You see the problem with that, right?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: I'm not in your classroom. Just tell me the answer. Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: The chain reaction will grow and grow, never stopping until all the uranium fissions. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV (cont'd) The fuel quickly burns out, releasing a massive amount of energy in an instant. This is the principle behind a nuclear bomb. So: (the sketch) Control rods. See... these rods are the fuel rods. They contain the uranium. These rods are control rods. They're made of boron. Now-- why do you think they're-- Oh. Right. Not in a classroom.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: They're made of boron because it's excellent at capturing neutrons. It absorbs them. If you lower a control rod between two fuel rods, it acts like a bullet proof vest, keeping these neutrons from smashing into these atoms, and the reaction slows. If you raise it, the fuel rods can fire neutrons at each other, and the reaction increases. Water is pumped through the core, the heat of fission turns it to steam, and the result: electricity. Shcherbina reaches out and takes the sketch. Studies it.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: And the graphite?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Ah-- the neutrons are moving so fast-- we call this "flux"-- it's relatively unlikely that they'll hit other uranium atoms. To make the chain reaction possible, you have to slow them down. In the RBMK reactors, we surround the fuel rods with graphite to moderate-- slow down-- the neutron flux. Shcherbina stares at the sketch. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Good. I know how a nuclear reactor works. Now I don't need you. Shcherbina leans back in his seat and closes his eyes to sleep. A happy little smile on his face.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impossibly gray, Soviet building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portrait of LENIN. Khomyuk sits across from it on a squat couch. Tense. From behind a closed door, we hear MEN LAUGHING. A sheepish female AIDE, 60's, sits at a desk near the doo

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you came back another-- ?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I've waited three hours. I can wait longer. The DOOR OPENS, and two men emerge in good spirits. One i CHULKOV, 50's. The other is GARANIN, 57, overfed.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: Wonderful... just wonderful...

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: (rises) Deputy Secretary Garanin. Garanin doesn't drop his smile, but he glances over to hi aide, who looks like a dog about to get beaten. Who's thi

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Ulana Khomyuk of the Byelorusian Institute for Nuclear Energy. The slightest hitch in his smile. Then right back to:

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: Oh? What a pleasure. May I introduce Ilya Ivanovich Chulkov, the eminent poet? We were just discussing--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I'm here about Chernobyl. Garanin's smile freezes on his face. Then to Chulkov. Guides him warmly to the door.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: Such a lovely time. Please, visit again soon.  220 20. Chulkov heads out, confused. Garanin closes the door behi him, then turns back to Khomyuk. No longer smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours himself a glass of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: I must tell you-- this is why no one likes scientists. When we have a disease to cure, where are they? In a lab. Noses in their books. And so, grandma dies. He crosses to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: But when there isn't a problem? They're everywhere. Spreading fear.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I know about Chernobyl.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I know the core is either partially or completely exposed.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Whatever that means.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: And I know that if you don't immediately issue iodine tablets and then evacuate this city, hundreds of thousands will get cancer, and god only knows how many will die. For a moment, her fear rattles him. But only for a moment

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: Yes, very good, there has been an accident at Chernobyl, but I have been assured there is no problem.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I'm telling you there is.  221 222 223 21.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: I prefer my opinion to yours.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I'm a nuclear physicist. Before you were Deputy Secretary, you worked in a shoe factory.

dialogues.speaker: GARANIN
dialogues.text: (stiffens) Yes. I worked in a shoe factory. And now I'm in charge. (raises his glass) "To the workers of the world." He downs his drink. Meeting over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Khomyuk walks out of Garanin's office. Closes the door behind her. His AIDE looks nervous. Khomyuk fishes the PILL BOTTLE out of her purse.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Stable iodine will keep your thyroid from absorbing radioactive iodine. Take one pill each day for as long as they last. And go east-- as far away from Minsk as you can. Khomyuk hands her the pills, and exits. The aide stares at the pills, then quickly takes one and shoves the bottle into her own purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyudmilla pushes her way through the throngs of miserable people. The hallways are choked with sick people. Some are being treated while they lie on the floor. We he the sound of a SCREAMING BABY from off-screen. Lyudmilla sees a nurse coming toward her.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: Can you help me, I'm looking for--  22. The nurse doesn't acknowledge her. Just rushes by. Lyudmilla turns a corner and stops when she sees: Oksana' husband MIKHAIL, standing in the corridor. He's holding his baby, who is screaming-- not a wail of hunger or fatigue, but the sharp, staccato cry of PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: Lyudmilla. She stares in shock at him. His eyes are bloodshot. Face puffy. Both his and his baby's skin are reddish/tan. She approaches and sees that he's standing in front of a window looking into a TREATMENT ROOM. THROUGH THE WINDOW - she sees OKSANA and her FOUR-YEAR OL SON in the room - both sharing a single gurney. Oksana's dress is covered in vomit. ZINCHENKO, her hand BANDAGED, is hooking the four-year ol up to an IV. The little boy's head lolls... he doesn't ev react when Zinchenko pushes the needle in. They're both TANNED... just like Mikhail and the baby.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: Take her.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: What? He extends his baby out to her.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: Take her. Take her away from here. He retches, then holds the baby out again. Raising his volume to be heard over his daughter's SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: MIKHAIL
dialogues.text: Please. Take her. Take her. Lyudmilla, scared, reaches out for the baby when:

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT NURSE
dialogues.text: Get away from them! The Pripyat Nurse rushes over to Lyudmilla. Starts pushin her back from Mikhail.  224 23.

dialogues.speaker: PRIPYAT NURSE
dialogues.text: You want to get sick? Go! Lyudmilla backs away, then turns and rushes away. Mikhail is still holding his baby out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lyudmilla rounds the corner, then finally stops. Covers h mouth with a shaky hand. Overwhelmed. Then sees: a MILITARY OFFICER, MAJOR BUROV, 45, passing b She runs to catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me... I am Vasily Ignatenko's wife...

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR BUROV
dialogues.text: (no time for her) I don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: No, he's a fireman. Ignatenko. Ignatenko. 6th Paramilitary Fire and Rescue Unit... I have to find him... (stops him) Please. Burov relents. He pulls a folded paper from his pocket. A list of names. Scans it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR BUROV
dialogues.text: Ignatenko. He's being transported by helicopter to Moscow. Hospital #6.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: Why? Is he all right? Can I see him?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR BUROV
dialogues.text: (enough already) You want to see him? Go to Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: But-- we're not allowed out of-- They arrive at a hallway guarded by soldiers. Lyudmilla c no longer follow him.  225 226 227 24.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR BUROV
dialogues.text: You have permission. Tell them Major Burov sent you. He walks down the hall. She calls out after him.

dialogues.speaker: LYUDMILLA
dialogues.text: When are they taking him?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR BUROV
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VASILY - on a gurney - is loaded into a HELICOPTER along with some other firefighters and plant workers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopters sweep by in formation. A moment, then... The COMMISSION HELICOPTERS blow into frame, heading in th opposite direction... moving toward Chernobyl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot calls back to the men in the back.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: We're approaching the power plant. Shcherbina looks out the small side window. From his vantage, nothing but green forest and blue skies.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Beautiful. You should enjoy this view, Legasov. While you have one. Legasov ignores that. He's craning his neck. Left... right... which way? The helicopter BANKS, and he sees: SMOKE... which is blown away to reveal: CHERNOBYL - tilted toward him through the helicopter window... the reactor building blown open... the fire pouring out of the center... and a faint BLUE GLOW flickering around the air over the reactor... And scattered on the roof, CHUNKS of BLACK GRAPHITE.  25.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (to himself) What have they done? Shcherbina is just as shocked. Never expected this.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Can you see the core from here?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I don't need to. Look at the graphite on the roof. The entire building's blown open. It's exposed.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I don't see how you can tell For god's sake, look at the that from here-- glow-- the radiation is ionizing the air!

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: If we can't see it, we don't know. (to the pilot) Get us directly over the building.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Boris Evdokimovich-- Don't use my name.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: --if we fly directly over an I didn't ask your advice. open reactor core--

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: --we'll be dead within a week. Dead. The soldiers look at each other. And in the front, the pilot registers what was just said.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Sir? Shcherbina's face is set in grim determination.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: I have my orders from General- Secretary Gorbachev. You have your orders from me. Get us over the reactor core, or I'll have you shot. Legasov UNBUCKLES himself. Turns toward the cockpit.  228 229 26.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: If you fly over the core, I promise you-- by tomorrow morning, you'll be begging for that bullet. ON THE PILOT - sweating... three seconds from the reactor... two seconds... one second... The pilot YANKS on the stick. LEGASOV tumbles from his seat, SLAMMING into the side of the helicopter as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the helicopter PEELS OFF at the last moment and heads AWAY from the reactor. And one by one, the trailing helicopters peel off and FOLLOW...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION - SMOKE swirls - men in PROTECTIVE GEAR emerg silently from the cloud. White jumpsuits. Black gloves. T fashion of the apocalypse. WIDE TO REVEAL - THE SITE - workers, some in protective gear, others wearing only military uniforms, are building makeshift camp. Trucks, crates... and LIGHTS. Generators crank to life and light FLOODS the site, catching waves o soot passing through their beams. In the distance-- Chernobyl, and the plume of black smoke... FOMIN follows BRYUKHANOV through the gauntlet of soldiers He glances at the men in PROTECTIVE SUITS...

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Overkill. Pikalov's showing off. To make us look bad.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter how it looks. Bryukhanov stops. A stiff BREEZE has picked up. Fomin joi him. They're looking at: the COMMISSION HELICOPTERS landi on the ground nearby. Rotors kicking up a dusty wind.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Shcherbina's a pure bureaucrat, as stupid as he is pigheaded. We'll tell him the truth in the simplest terms possible, and we'll be fine. (yells to) Pikalov!  27. GENERAL VLADIMIR PIKALOV - 62, lifelong veteran, is signi orders for his men. He looks over at Bryukhanov with all resentment of decades of taking orders from bureaucrats. As he heads toward them: THEIR POV OF - THE HELICOPTER - the SOLDIERS have exited, along with the PILOT. Now SHCHERBINA gets out, followed by LEGASOV. Shcherbina speaks briefly to the soldiers, then begins crossing to Bryukhanov, Fomin and Pikalov. The soldiers stay behind with Legasov and the pilot. Not with them. Guarding them. As Shcherbina nears Bryukhanov:

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Shcherbina-- Chief Engineer Fomin, Colonel-General Pikalov and I are honored by your arrival.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Deeply, deeply honored.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: (shut up, Fomin) Naturally, we regret the circumstances of the visit, but as you can see, we're making excellent progress containing the damage. We've also begun an inquiry into the cause of the accident, and I have a list of individuals we believe are accountable. Bryukhanov hands Shcherbina a paper with a list of NAMES. Shcherbina takes it with an approving GRUNT, and removes some reading glasses from his jacket pocket. BY THE HELICOPTER - Legasov looks out toward the reactor. Acid fear in his stomach. THEN: one of the SOLDIERS from the helicopter approaches. Nods at Legasov to follow. SHCHERBINA - stands with Bryukhanov and Fomin-- a united front-- silently confronting the approaching Legasov. The

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Professor Legasov. I understand you've been saying dangerous things.  28.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Very dangerous things. (his preening speech) Apparently our reactor core "exploded." Please tell me how an RBMK reactor core "explodes". I'd love to know. Legasov glares at Fomin with pure hatred.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I'm not prepared to explain it at this time.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: (pleased) As I presumed. He has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Disgraceful, really. To spread disinformation at a time like this. Shcherbina stares at Legasov. Weighing his fate? Legasov meets his eyes. If this is his end, so be it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (to Bryukhanov) Why did I see graphite on the roof? Bryukhanov is startled by the question. So is Legasov.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Graphite is only found in the core, where it's used as a neutron flux moderator-- correct? Holy shit. Bryukhanov passes the buck immediately to:

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Fomin, why did the Deputy Chairman see graphite on the roof?

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: There can't be, I-- Comrade Shcherbina, my apologies, but graphite? That's... that's not possible. (scrambling) Perhaps you saw burnt concrete?  230 29.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Ah, now there you made a mistake, because while I don't know much about nuclear reactors, I know a lot about concrete.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: (panicking) Comrade, I assure you--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: I understand. You think Legasov is wrong. So-- how shall we prove it? No answer. Shcherbina turns to Pikalov. Well?

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: Our high-range dosimeter just arrived. We could cover one of our trucks with lead shielding, mount the dosimeter on the front... Shcherbina turns to Legasov. Satisfied? Legasov nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (to Pikalov) Have one of your men drive as close to the fire as he can, and give him every bit of protection you have. But understand-- even with the lead shielding-- it may not be enough. Pikalov understands. And doesn't hesitate.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: Then I'll do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoky haze from the fire, visible in the nearly-full moon blankets the ground. The air occasionally flickers with an eerie fluorescent glow. No one here. No movement, no life. Until. HEADLIGHTS appear - an ARMORED TRUCK approaches from the east... INTERCUT WITH - PIKALOV, driving the truck, in full gear. Gas mask concealing his face.  231 30. ON THE FRONT OF THE TRUCK - a large DOSIMETER, blinking lights, secured to the grill with MASKING TAPE. PIKALOV'S POV - through the windowscreen - the POWER PLAN CHAIN LINK FENCE - and beyond it, the back side of Reacto Building #4 - and the fire raging from within... He slows as he approaches the gate. Stop. Hesitates. Then TURNS AROUND. Starts to drive away. Then STOPS again. ON PIKALOV - SHIFTING the truck into REVERSE, and: STOMPS on the ACCELERATOR, and: THE TRUCK - gears whining as it picks up speed, heading backwards, and: SMASHES through the GATE, sending chain link and steel poles scattering aside... The truck stops again, then turns slowly to face its destination. PIKALOV'S POV - through the windowscreen - as he drives SLOWLY NOW, his headlights illuminate the desolate landscape of the broken power plant. We stay in his POV as he weaves through: chunks of burnin graphite. The wreckage of pumps and machinery thrown from somewhere deep in the building... And as he turns around to the west side of the building: ABANDONED FIRE TRUCKS... OPEN HOSES still connected to th plant hydrants, SPEWING WATER into drainage grates... ON PIKALOV - he turns the wheel, searching for the closes spot, and as he comes around a turn, we can see his eyes widen, even through the goggles of his face mask... Because he sees it now. And reflected against his windshield-- --a terrible, UNNATURAL light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A temporary command tent. Bryukhanov and Fomin sit in silence. Across the room, Legasov sits alone.  232 31. And in the middle of the room, between them... Shcherbina Waiting with no expression whatsoever. No one looks at anyone. No one says a word. Then-- a SOLDIER enters.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: He's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shcherbina strides out, followed by Legasov, Bryukhanov a Fomin. The armored truck is 100 meters away, and men in protective gear are HOSING IT DOWN with a WHITE FOAM. Twenty meters away, men hose down PIKALOV - still in his gear - and then help him remove his hood... gas mask... unzip the overalls... he unbuckles the boots... Finally, Pikalov walks over to them.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: It's not three roentgen. They hang in anticipation. Everyone's fate in the balance

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: It's fifteen thousand. Legasov closes his eyes. That was the number he expected. Fomin is speechless. Bryukhanov scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV
dialogues.text: Comrade Shcherbina-- Shcherbina fixes his deadly glare on Bryukhanov, who instantly shuts up. Then Shcherbina turns to Legasov.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: What does that number mean?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: It means the core is open and the fuel is melting down. It means the fire we're watching with our own eyes is giving off nearly twice the radiation released by the bomb in Hiroshima. And that's every single hour. Hour after hour. (checks his watch) Twenty hours since the explosion. Forty bombs' worth by now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV (cont'd) Forty-eight more tomorrow. And it will not stop. Not in a week. Not in a month. It will burn and spread its poison until the entire continent is dead. No one says a word. Then Shcherbina turns to a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Please escort Comrades Bryukhanov and Fomin to the local Party headquarters. Just as Bryukhanov foresaw. They're being arrested.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Thank you for your service, gentlemen. Bryukhanov attempts a protest, even as he knows it's pointless.

dialogues.speaker: BRYUKHANOV SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Comrade... You're excused. Discussion over. Two more soldiers move in and guide Bryukhanov and Fomin away.

dialogues.speaker: FOMIN
dialogues.text: Dyatlov was in charge! It was Dyatlov! And they're gone. Shcherbina takes a moment. Doesn't noti Legasov's disquiet about what just happened. Just:

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Tell me how to put it out.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: We'll use helicopters. Drop water on it, like a forest fire.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: No-- no-- you don't understand. You're dealing with something that has never occurred on this planet before. This isn't a "fire". It's a fissioning reactor core burning at over 2,000 degrees. The heat will instantly vaporize the water-- or worse, ionize it, and then you're--  33.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (no time) How do we--

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Sand. Sand and boron. Thousands of drops because the helicopters can't go directly over the core, so much of it is going to miss, and there are other-- risks-- but I don't see any other way.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: How much sand and boron?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Well I can't be as accurate as I'd--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: For god's sake-- roughly.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Five thousand tons? Shcherbina and Pikalov look at each other. Five thousand

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: And obviously we need to immediately evacuate an enormous area of--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (bristles) Never mind that. Focus on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I am focusing on the fire. The wind is carrying the smoke, all that radiation-- at least evacuate Pripyat! It's three kilometers away!

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: That's my decision to make.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Then make it.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: I've been told not to.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Is it or is it not your decision?!  233 234 34.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: I am in charge here! This will go much easier if you talk to me about things you DO understand, and do NOT talk to me about things you do NOT understand. With that Shcherbina turns and walks off in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (shouts after him) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: (shouts back) I'm GOING to get you five thousand tons of sand and boron! And just like that, he's gone. Legasov stands there, unsu of what to do. Or where to go.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: There's a hotel. Legasov looks at him. A hotel? It's all so surreal... but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A six storey, white building. Typical Soviet brutalist design. Could just as easily be a prison. Legasov is dropped off by a Red Army UAZ-469, which drive away, leaving him alone. He looks around, still in shock. A FEW CITIZENS - take their nightly strolls. Walk their pets. No one knows. And he can't tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legasov slowly walks through the lobby, like he's ina waking nightmare. The hotel is quiet, but there are the bellhops... the front desk attendants... the maids... He turns and sees: a BAR off to the side. He crosses over to it and takes a seat. Everything feels upside-down. Around the bend of the bar, a couple. HUSBAND and WIFE fr the looks of it. 30's, probably locals. Sharing a quiet b merry conversation. Perhaps a birthday night out.  35. The BARTENDER, 20-ish woman, unscrews the cap on a bottle of vodka and takes a upturned glass from the bar. Legasov points to one of the glasses that are FACE DOWN on the ba

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I'd prefer one of those. She looks at him oddly. Uhh, okay. She takes one of the glasses he wants, and pours him his drink. The HUSBAND AND WIFE have stopped chatting. They've notic this. Legasov doesn't realize they're looking at him unti

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL WIFE
dialogues.text: Moscow? He looks over at her. What? Oh. His clothes... or his fac He nods. Lost.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL WIFE
dialogues.text: Superstitious? Your strange request about the glass? Oh. Yeah. Superstitious. He turns back to his drink, but:

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL WIFE
dialogues.text: Are you here because of the fire? Please stop asking questions. Legasov nods. Yes. The wife and husband share a look. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL WIFE
dialogues.text: Anything we should be worried about? Legasov turns to them. They're trying to disguise their concern... their fear... but doing a poor job of it. A long pause. Tell them. Tell them. Tell them.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: No. The couple do another poor job of disguising their relief They each raise a glass to him. He raises his to them, an then he drinks. Fast. CLOSE ON LEGASOV: the bottle enters frame. Pours another. We stay CLOSE ON LEGASOV, soaking in his fear and guilt a frustration, and all sound FADES TO SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE MOVE SILENTLY IN THE AIR - over the pine forest. What started as a narrow band of reddish/brown trees has widened. Death is spreading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick mist hangs over the ground. The only sound is the occasional creak of wood. The mist shifts, and now we see the forest floor. Blanket in dead pine needles. The corpse of a deer. Now we hear: a faint whup-whup-whup-whup In the distance, PINE NEEDLES are blown off of dead trees... the sound grows to a DEAFENING ROAR... the wave air and pine needles rushes closer, and: LOOK UP THROUGH THE TREES TO SEE: a squadron of SOVIET AI FORCE HELICOPTERS flying by in formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopters bank around toward Chernobyl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV stands on the roof, watching the helicopters through binoculars. Shcherbina stands next to him. Behind them, set up on a small portable table, is a STASIUK, a RADIO OFFICER with radio and microphone. We hear the squawk of voices over the radio.  37.

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Boris squadron, maintain altitude, hold at 5 kilometers. Anna squadron proceed to pattern. Lead One begin approach. Keep clear of the construction cranes on the south edge of the zone, and move in from the east. As Legasov watches, four helicopters come closer. Three remain in a holding pattern while the LEAD COPTER begins move slowly toward the reactor site.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Anna squadron to pattern, Lead One on approach from east. The lead helicopter BANKS as it begins to move toward the PLUME OF SMOKE. Legasov watches. Nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Remind them about the perimeter. Stasiuk looks to Shcherbina for the okay on that. Shcherbina scowls. Doesn't like taking orders from Legaso But nods. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: STASIUK
dialogues.text: (into mic) They cannot fly directly over the fire. A minimum of a ten meter perimeter.

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Ten meter perimeter, copy. A bit of static, then:

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Lead One, per preflight-- maintain minimum ten meter perimeter.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Cop[distortion]. Legasov continues to peer through the binoculars. Shcherbina just watches with his eyes. Unblinking. The helicopter moves slowly toward the plume of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Forty meters. [distortion]-five Thirty.  38. The smoke suddenly SHIFTS, and washing over the helicopte partially obscuring it. Legasov lowers the binoculars. He's lost sight of the copter. ON THE RADIO - the signal is starting to distort. Then:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: (breaking up) --visibility, I [can't]-- (breaking up) --twent[y]--

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Lead One, repeat.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: [distortion] are we [distortion]

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Repeat. Repeat. The wind shifts, and the smoke moves away, briefly REVEALING THE COPTER. It's drifting RIGHT OVER THE FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: No no no-- they're too close. The smoke returns, OBSCURING THE HELICOPTER again. Stasiuk looks to Shcherbina.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (no time for this) They cannot go over the core-- tell them! Shcherbina gives Stasiuk another nod. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: STASIUK
dialogues.text: Lead One is too close, I repeat they are too close!

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Copy. (beat) Lead One, you are inside the perimeter. Abort. Abort.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: [distortion] can't [distortion]  39. As the wind buffets the smoke, we catch GLIMPSES of the helicopter. It's hovering RIGHT OVER THE FIRE, now facing the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: STASIUK
dialogues.text: Abort. Abort. Abort.

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND
dialogues.text: Abort abort. Lead One--

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: [distorted] I can't [distorted] oh... oh... [distorted] ON THE RADIO - LOUD STATIC... worse than silence. Then: Legasov, Shcherbina and Stasiuk watch in horror as the wi shifts the smoke away, revealing: The helicopter is still just hovering there. Right over t mouth of the open reactor.

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: Lead One. Lead One. Nothing. Radio silence. And then the helicopter slowly DRIFTS toward a CONSTRUCTI CRANE... off kilter, tilting ODDLY as if drunk... .В»..and its rotor blades STRIKE the steel cable hanging the crane... the BLADES DISINTEGRATE, and-- --the helicopter ROLLS OVER and PLUMMETS from the sky. Legasov turns away. Doesn't want to look. But he hears th distant THUD of the impact. His stomach turns. Shcherbina hangs his head. The worst possible beginning. The radio's distorted signal drops to a muted HISS. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BASE COMMAND, (RADIO)
dialogues.text: (solemn) Please advise.

dialogues.speaker: STASIUK
dialogues.text: (shaken) Sir? What do I tell the others?

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Legasov. (nothing) Legasov, is there another way to do this?  240 241 242 243 244 245 246 247 40. Legasov shakes his head "no". Shcherbina turns back to Stasiuk.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Send the next one in. And tell them to approach from the west. Legasov walks away. Overwhelmed. Shcherbina lets him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most Soviet building imaginable. A four story, brown box with a band of ugly orange tiling just under the roof We hear a PHONE RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARINA, 40's, scientist in a lab, answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Kurchatov Institute Laboratory 4. INTERCUT WITH: KHOMYUK, in her lab, on the phone. Dmitri sits with her, listening to Khomyuk's end of the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Marina Gruzinskaya, it's Ulana Khomyuk from Minsk. 240 241 242 243 244 245 246 247  41. Marina tenses. Already knows what this is about. Glances her phone, with its lit up buttons. This is a nuclear lab in the Soviet Union. No such thing as a private call.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: (stiffly pleasant) Oh, yes, how nice of you to phone. It's been too long. Khomyuk registers the woman's tone. Good.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: It has. I was actually calling about our friend-- you know, the one in the country?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I wanted to see how he was doing. It's so hot there right now.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Yes, it's extremely hot. But-- (thinks) His nephews are flying in, and they always bring cool weather with them.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Oh? Which nephews?

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: Simka, who's 14, and little Boris, who just turned 5. Khomyuk looks at the small reference PERIODIC TABLE taped on the wall under some cabinets. Sees the symbols for Si (14) and B (5).

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Well that's wonderful. Of course, children can make you even hotter when they're crawling all over you.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: That's true. But what can you do?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll go visit them.  42.

dialogues.speaker: MARINA
dialogues.text: No, they don't want visitors. I'm sorry, I have to get back to work. It's very busy right now. Goodbye. Khomyuk hears the CLICK as Marina hangs up. She puts the phone down.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: They're dropping sand and boron on the fire.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: It's what I would do.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure it is. She moves across the lab to a low storage unit with wide drawers. Begins pulling open the drawers, looking for-- --there. A set of BLUEPRINTS. She puts them on her desk. Dmitri joins her, curious, as she hunts through the blueprints for something. Flip, flip, flip, flip -- there An elevation of an industrial building. HER FINGER traces down... to a cross-section of two EMPTY SPACES. She thinks for a second, then FOLDS UP the blueprints and moves to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: DMITRI
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: (not looking back) Chernobyl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minimalist suite. Bedroom with an attached area for a sofa, chair, coffee table. On it, plates of untouched foo Ashtrays full of cigarettes. They've been holed up in here for a bit. LEGASOV stands by the window. Staring out and down at something-- perhaps on the street below. We don't see wha From outside, the steady drone of distant HELICOPTERS. SHCHERBINA enters. Legasov turns to him. News?  43.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: It's been smooth. Twenty drops. No change in Legasov's somber expression. Shcherbina's short fuse is immediately lit.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: There are fifty thousand people in this city. So. This argument again.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Professor Ilyin-- who is also on the commission-- says the radiation isn't high enough to evacuate--

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Ilyin isn't a physicist--

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: He's a medical doctor. If he says it's safe, it's safe.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Not if they stay here.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: We're staying here...

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Yes we are. And we'll be dead in five years. The second the words leave his mouth, Legasov regrets the Shcherbina stands in total shock. Gutted.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: I'm-- I'm sorry, I didn't-- Shcherbina limply waves him off. Stop talking. He sits down. Trying to swallow what he's just been told. THE PHONE RINGS. Jars us. Shcherbina picks it up, in a da

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Shcherbina.  249 250
Legasov watches Shcherbina's face as he listens to the person on the other end. After a few long seconds...

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Thank you. He hangs up. All of the fight gone out of him.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: A nuclear plant in Sweden detected radiation. And identified it as a byproduct of our fuel. The Americans took satellite photos-- the reactor building. The smoke. The fire. The whole world knows. Shcherbina joins Legasov at the window. Stares out. Pale.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: The wind's been blowing toward Germany. They're not letting children play outside in Frankfurt. THEIR POV: CHILDREN at a playground just across the stree MUSIC: the familiar ABC NIGHTLY NEWS fanfare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As children laugh and play, we hear the voice of:

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There has been a nuclear accident in the Soviet Union, and the Soviets have admitted that it happened. In the near distance, the PLUME OF BLACK SMOKE continues rise from Chernobyl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorbachev sits alone, watching a VHS PLAYBACK of a Wester news report on television. Grim.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The Soviet version is this: one of the atomic reactors at the Chernobyl Atomic Power Plant near the city of Kiev was damaged, and there is speculation in Moscow that people were injured and may have died. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 251 252 45. PETER JENNINGS (ON TV) (cont'd) The Soviets may have been fairly quick to acknowledge the accident because evidence-- in the form of mild nuclear radiation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcycle parked on the left shoulder of a WINDING HIGHWAY in the middle of nowhere. A young man is attempti to fix a thrown chain. His girlfriend stands waiting. Smoking.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --had already reached beyond the Soviet borders to Scandinavia. An EMPTY KIEV CITY BUS rounds the bend and ROARS past the heading north down the highway. Then another. And another. And another. The girl nudges her boyfriend to get his attention. He rises, and they both watch in confusion as: Kiev city buses keep coming, one after the other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People walk outside. Push prams. Carry groceries. A MILITARY truck rumbles into view. There are LOUDSPEAKER mounted to the truck. A PIERCING electronic SQUEAL. A female voice echoes out from the loudspeakers. A recording. Slow, deliberate, oddly calm.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENTION.
dialogues.text: And despite the eerie sedation of her voice, the people o the street immediately begin BACKING AWAY from the truck. Frightened. Whatever this is, it won't be good.
The LOUDSPEAKER TRUCKS are everywhere, crawling at a snail's pace through the city.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENTION.
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS begin moving in formation toward groups of peopl who put their arms up, submissively moving backwards.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS AFTER THE EXPLOSION
dialogues.text: Soldiers are stopping cars. Gesturing for people to get out. Leave the cars... leave everything in the cars...

dialogues.speaker: OF PRIPYAT.
dialogues.text: Soldiers head into buildings. Fists POUND on doors.

dialogues.speaker: STATION IN THE CITY OF PRIPYAT--
dialogues.text: The KIEV BUSES begin arriving. Soldiers clear people out stores. Panicky parents grab their children from playgrou Teachers leads students out of school in single file line

dialogues.speaker: VICINITY ARE DETERIORATING.
dialogues.text: In the HOSPITAL - soldiers move through the hallways. Ush patients out of bed. People are removing their own IV's.. Soldiers push the incapacitated out in gurneys. Even they cannot stay. ZINCHENKO is treating MIKHAIL and OKSANA'S BABY, who is still shrieking in Mikhail's arms.  47.

dialogues.speaker: NECESSARY STEPS TO COMBAT THIS.
dialogues.text: A soldier gestures for her to leave. She refuses. He grab her. Another soldier takes the baby from Mikhail, who tri to stop them, but he has no strength. All he can do is cr Zinchenko fights to get to the baby, but they DRAG her away.

dialogues.speaker: POSSIBLE--
dialogues.text: ON THE STREETS - people are being lined up to board buses Scared, but compliant. Like livestock. Nearby, a CRYING LITTLE GIRL. Alone. A soldier enters and casually LIFTS HER and takes her away. No one says a word

dialogues.speaker: TOWNS OF KIEV OBLAST.
dialogues.text: People file into the streets, all under the watchful eye soldiers. Some of them are barely dressed.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE AND THE CITY OFFICIALS.
dialogues.text: Outside, ZHARKOV, the elderly Pripyat minister who gave t rousing speech in the Chernobyl command bunker, is helped toward a bus by a soldier. The old Soviet believer seems utterly confused. He doesn' understand... they were told it was safe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the buses, the soldiers start taking PETS away... adul and children CRYING as dogs, cats, rabbits, hamsters... a pulled from their arms. The people are going. The animals are staying.

dialogues.speaker: SHUT THE WINDOWS.
dialogues.text: NEAR THE HOSPITAL - Hundreds of patients on gurneys. Even more stumbling around in hospital gowns. Soldiers trying get them into ambulances. Onto buses. ZINCHENKO leans over a RUBBISH BIN. Vomiting. She finishe and stands back up weakly. Looks at her hand. It's oozing fluid through the bandage. Her other hand is bright red now. Blistering. The Pripyat Nurse rushes over and leads Zinchenko to an ambulance. She stumbles toward it. It doesn't matter now. She's dying.

dialogues.speaker: EVACUATION.
dialogues.text: The BUSES full of people begin to pull away... one after another in a line... abandoned PET DOGS run after the buses, trying to stay with their owners... ON THE ROOF OF THE POLISSYA HOTEL - Legasov and Shcherbin watch the evacuation in somber silence. From here, we can see the scope of it. The soldiers. The military vehicles. The abandoned cars. The dogs and cats. The circling helicopters. The Soviet flags. The propaganda billboards. And the endless convoy of buses as they drive away with t former citizens of Pripyat. This time, it's Shcherbina who can't look. This time, it' Shcherbina who turns and walks away. And the loudspeaker recording begins again.  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last of the buses rumbles past the military checkpoint, a small CAR comes driving up toward the town. Soldiers step out, hands raised. A few more ready their rifles. The car slows to a stop. ZUKAUSKAS, a soldier, moves toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: NO ENTRY. TURN AROUND.
dialogues.text: But instead, KHOMYUK rolls down her window. There are a dozen men with guns. She's terrified. But defiant.

dialogues.speaker: ZUKAUSKAS
dialogues.text: I said turn around. This is a restricted zone.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I'm from the Byelorusian Institute of Nuclear-- SOUND: a HELICOPTER ZOOMS BY overhead. LOW. She flinches from the noise. The wind. This isn't where she belongs.

dialogues.speaker: ZUKAUSKAS
dialogues.text: Do you have permission?

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I need to--

dialogues.speaker: ZUKAUSKAS
dialogues.text: Turn around right now, or I will arrest you. Only one option left. She gathers her courage.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: If you arrest me, you should take me to the highest possible authority. Another HELICOPTER rockets by. The guards look at each other. What is this woman on about?  255 256 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Red Army UAZ-469 drives up to the hotel. There are ligh on in the lower windows. All of the windows above the fir storey are dark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The type of place where you might have a wedding. The fan lights and carpet are a strange contrast to Legasov and Shcherbina, who sit at a banquet table, looking at a larg MAP of the region. Legasov smokes as he talks. Shcherbina barely looks at th map. Seems lost in his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: We have to start a radiological survey. Sector by sector. On foot-- dosimeters in hand-- Legasov realizes Shcherbina isn't listening.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Are you all right? Shcherbina lifts his head. Forces a reassuring smile. The PIKALOV enters with KHOMYUK.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt. The guards arrested this woman at the south checkpoint. I would have put her ina cell, but--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: --but he thought you should know that I know. Before Legasov can even ask--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I know your reactor core is exposed. I know the graphite is on fire, the fuel is melting, and you're dropping sand and boron on it. Which you probably thought was smart. But you've made a mistake. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KHOMYUK (cont'd) (beat) Ulana Yuriyvna Khomyuk, chief physicist, Byelorusian Institute for Nuclear Energy. You're Valery Alexeyevich Legasov? He nods. A bit bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Smothering the core will put the fire out, but the temperature will eventually increase. It will melt down-- He raises a hand to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Believe me, I'm perfectly aware. But I estimate at least a month before it melts through the lower concrete pad, which gives us time to--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: You don't have a month. You have approximately two days. Before Legasov can respond, she puts the BLUEPRINTS down top of their map. Points to the bottom of the reactor.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Yes, the fuel would take a month to reach the concrete pad here, but first it's going to burn through the biological shield here by Tuesday. And when it does, it's going to hit these tanks. Bubbler pools. Reser--

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Reservoirs for the ECS. I understand your concern, but I confirmed it with plant personnel-- the tanks are nearly empty.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: No. They were nearly empty. That gets Legasov's attention. He leans in, concerned, as she points to the blueprints again.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Each of these points, here, here, here in the reactor hall... all drain to the bubbler pools.  257 258 52. Legasov leans back. Beginning to understand.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: I'm guessing every pipe in the building ruptured. And then there are those fire engines I saw on the way in. Pikalov turns to Legasov.

dialogues.speaker: PIKALOV
dialogues.text: The fire hoses are still connected. They've been gushing water into the structure this whole time.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (horrified) The tanks are full... Shcherbina is utterly confused, but he can see from Legasov's face-- something has gone terribly wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ugly globe-and-red-star logo of the Soviet nightly ne program VREMYA ("time") gives way to an oddly-framed newsdesk in front of a large blue screen. A female newsreader calmly reads a 14-second report. This is footage of the actual newscast made on April 28th, 198 Translation only is SUBTITLED over the footage.

dialogues.speaker: VREMYA NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: An official announcement from the Council of Ministers. There has been an accident at the Chernobyl atomic power station. One of the atomic reactors was damaged. Steps are being taken to deal with the situation, and aid is being given to those affected. The government has formed a commission of inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The commission is assembled, waiting, including Legasov, Shcherbina and Khomyuk, who sits with them. Gorbachev enters. Weary. Visibly stressed. Everyone rises and sits back down quickly as he takes his seat.  53.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: I have ten minutes. Then I'm back on the phone. Apologizing to our friends. Apologizing to our enemies. He glares at Legasov and Shcherbina.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Our power comes from the perception of our power. Do you understand the damage this has done? Do you understand what's at stake? (beat) Boris.

dialogues.speaker: SHCHERBINA
dialogues.text: Professor Legasov will deliver our briefing. Gorbachev leans back. This isn't the stubborn, bull-heade Shcherbina he knows. This man seems sullen, defeated... Legasov stands up, eager to draw attention from Shcherbin

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: We do have-- some-- good news. The air drops are working to douse the fire. There has been a reduction in radionuclide emissions, but the fire will not be extinguished for at least another two weeks. Gorbachev hangs his head. Two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: There is also-- an additional problem. Gorbachev slowly raises his eyes. There's more? Legasov opens a document binder in front of him. Everyone in the room has the same one in front of them. As Legasov turns pages, so do they, en masse. The first page is a CROSS SECTION of the REACTOR.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Nuclear fuel doesn't turn cold simply because it's not on fire. In fact, the temperature will likely rise as a result of the blanket of sand we've dropped. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGASOV (cont'd) The uranium will begin to melt the sand around it, creating a kind of-- lava-- which will begin to melt down through the shield below.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: You've made... lava.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: (clears his throat) I had anticipated this. I believed we had time to reinforce this lower concrete pad before the lava reached the earth and contaminated the groundwater. But as it turns out, I was worried about the wrong thing. Legasov turns the page. We now see a closer section of th blueprint, focusing on the core and the pools underneath.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: It was my understanding the large water tanks under the reactor were essentially empty. (gestures to) This is Ulana Khomyuk of the Byelorusian Institute. Thanks to her insight, we are now aware that the tanks are, in fact, full.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: (impatient) Of water. What exactly is the problem here, Legasov? Legasov nods to Khomyuk who rises. He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: (the blueprint page) When the lava enters these tanks, it will instantly superheat and vaporize approximately 7000 cubic meters of water, causing a significant thermal explosion. The word "explosion" sits there for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: How significant? A beat. Then:  55.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: We estimate between two and four megatons. The men in the room react. My god. Khomyuk flips to the next page. The room flips along with her. The snap of papers moving. This is a map of the Pripyat/Chernobyl region. She makes CIRCLING gesture on the page with her finger.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: Everything within a 30 kilometer radius will be completely destroyed, including the other three nuclear reactors at Chernobyl. The entirety of radioactive material in all of the cores will be ejected at force, and dispersed by a massive shockwave-- She flips to the next page, and the room follows in turn. larger map. Byelorusia and Ukraine.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: --which will extend approximately 200 kilometers and likely be fatal to the entire population of Kiev as well as a portion of Minsk. Gorbachev lowers his head to his hand. Can't look. Doesn' want to hear any more. Khomyuk flips to the next page. The room follows. A map o Europe and Asia.

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: The release of radiation will be severe, and will impact all of Soviet Ukraine, Latvia, Lithuania and Byelorusia, as well as Poland, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Hungary, and most of East Germany. She sits down. Report concluded. Gorbachev takes a moment to absorb this, then:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: What do you mean "impact"?  56.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: For much of the area, a nearly permanent disruption of water and food supplies, and a steep increase in the rates of cancer and birth defects. I don't know how many will die, but-- many. He hesitates, then:

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: For Byelorusia and Ukraine, "impact" means completely uninhabitable. For a minimum of one hundred years. The men in the room are staggered.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: There are fifty million people in Byelorusia and Ukraine alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Sixty. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: How long before this happens?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: Approximately 48 to 72 hours. Khomyuk watches their panic rise. Good. Panic is appropriate.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: But-- we believe we have a solution. Legasov flips to the next page. A larger schematic of the power plant. The room flips along.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: We can pump the water from the tanks. Unfortunately, they're sealed off by a sluice gate, and the gate can only be opened manually from within the duct system itself. We need to find three plant workers who know the facility well enough to enter the basement here, find their way through all these ductways, get to the sluice gate valve here, and give us the access we need to pump out the tanks. (beat) Of course we'll need your permission.  259 57.

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Permission for what?

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: The water in these ducts-- the level of radioactive contamination--

dialogues.speaker: KHOMYUK
dialogues.text: (just say it) They'll likely be dead in a week.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: We're asking your permission to kill three men. Gorbachev considers that. Turns to a GENERAL. Some kind o silent communication between the two of them. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GORBACHEV
dialogues.text: Comrade Legasov. All victories inevitably come at a cost. Sometimes we count this cost in rubles. (beat) Sometimes we count it in lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SILENTLY DRIFT through the empty city... INSIDE CLASSROOMS - the desks are in an orderly grid. Soviet propaganda on the wall. Lessons on the chalkboard. OUTSIDE - tired, faded clothes hang from a drying line. IN THE HOSPITAL - the wide, empty corridor. And now different views. Equipment, beds, files... all scattered about. A steady DRIP from a cracked IV bottle. A BENCH ON THE STREET - a simple carving in the soft wood A worn pencil. IN AN APARTMENT - a pair of old shoes next to an unmade b A RESTAURANT - food still on tables, right where it was l THE FERRIS WHEEL - creaks gently in the breeze. We PAN SLOWLY across the desolate ghost city until we lan on: the POLISSYA HOTEL.  260 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shcherbina sits behind a table. Legasov stands next to hi pointing at the same facility schematic we just saw.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
dialogues.text: --and open the sluice gate valve here. Legasov turns away from the schematic to face: THE MEN - about thirty of them in civilian clothes, sitting on fanc banquet chairs, and staring back at him. Grim.

dialogues.speaker: LEGASOV
